author: Michael Larabel
description: EasyEffects is the open-source application formerly known as PulseEffects that transitioned to using native PipeWire filters for providing simple audio effects on the Linux desktop. EasyEffects makes it easy to apply different audio effects like bass enhancer, compressor, pitch shift, reverberation, and many more. With this week's release of EasyEffects 8.0, the user interface has been rewritten in Qt / QML / Kirigami rather than GTK4...
title: EasyEffects 8.0 Released In Porting From GTK4 To Qt / QML / Kirigami

author: Michael Larabel
description: Following yesterday's release of Rust Coreutils 0.4, GNU Coreutils 9.9 is now available as the latest update to this set of core utilities common to Linux systems and other platforms...
title: GNU Coreutils 9.9 Brings Numerous Fixes

author: Michael Larabel
description: Google Cloud today is rolling out their N4D compute instances that are optimized for cost/price-performance and geared for general purpose workloads. The N4D instances are powered by 5th Gen AMD EPYC "Turin" processors and offer very nice performance and value over their prior-generation general purpose VMs.
title: Google Cloud N4D Delivers Great VM Performance & Value Powered By AMD EPYC Turin

author: Michael Larabel
description: Last week when delivering some CachyOS benchmarks against Fedora 43 and Ubuntu 25.10 on the Framework Desktop with AMD Ryzen AI Max+, a few Phoronix readers wrote in with the question or belief that openSUSE Tumbleweed would better perform against CachyOS given the distribution's select x86_64-v3 packages and other advantages. As it's been a while since running any benchmarks of the rolling-release openSUSE Tumbleweed, here are those benchmarks now in the mix for seeing how the performance compares.
title: Can openSUSE Tumbleweed Compete With CachyOS Performance?

author: Michael Larabel
description: Whenever seeing Linux kernel mailing list patches from Google engineer Eric Biggers it tends to be about performance optimizations to the Linux kernel's cryptography subsystem. That was once again the case on Sunday with the newest patch series providing some nice gains...
title: POLYVAL Work Bringing More Performance Gains To Linux Crypto Subsystem

author: Michael Larabel
description: Tecent engineers have been working on addressing long-standing inefficiencies within the Linux kernel scheduler code around over-subscribed virtualized environments...
title: Tencent Proposes Semantics-Aware vCPU Scheduling For Over-Subscribed KVM Linux VMs

author: Michael Larabel
description: While LoongArch 64-bit is already part of the GCC compiler for the past several years, LoongArch 32-bit is now being proposed for the GNU Compiler Collection...
title: LoongArch LA32 Target Proposed For The GCC Compiler

author: Michael Larabel
description: For those still using an AMD GCN 1.1 "Sea Islands" GPU like the Radeon R9 290/390 series, HD 7790 / 8870, or other Radeon Rx 200 / Rx 300 series GPUs, there is an exciting early Christmas present this year. Timur Kristóf of Valve's Linux graphics driver team sent out the patch series on Sunday for enabling the GCN 1.1 GPUs to use the newer AMDGPU driver on Linux by default in place of the existing "Radeon" driver. This can mean better performance, Vulkan driver support out-of-the-box, and other improvements compared to using that older Radeon driver...
title: Patches Proposed For Radeon GCN 1.1 GPUs To Use AMDGPU Linux Driver By Default
